tweet: b'Thank you, whoever came up with fish and chips.'

b"@yorgakos @CuckSwarm @fraac1 Oh and it might look like a loop to an observer, but that is me being home doing the things I actually enjoy. I'll pop out every once in a while since it makes people happy, but there's so much more information in there.\n\nI wish I could finally grasp the hilbert curve encoding."

b'@yorgakos @CuckSwarm @fraac1 oh yeah covid really happened with the worst timing.

I have been feeling a creative drive fairly consistenly over the last couple of months rather the one-day spiked I used to get.

So like i open up software from time to time now, but there defintiely are new habits in place.'

b"@tylerguitar_ @fraac1 Now people want me to do more, and i'm super curious to see if I could make something interesting to the fans and I have a bunch of ideas, but I'm very lazy and now that I don't need a job, I can just do my very favorite thing all the time.\n\nThink about cubes and shit."

b"@tylerguitar_ @fraac1 Like I should've told the guy who was when I tried to give back the award for entrepreneur of the year because I'm not an entrepreneur:\n\nI'm not being humble, I literally just stumbled a successful product while looking for something else when seeing if I could actually do it."
b'@tylerguitar_ @fraac1 Yes, but nothing for the public.\n\nI do programming stuff all the time, just not in marketable forms.'

b"@yorgakos @muddyfiftysix yes, these requirements are since the soul, but money's made it easier to find via doing great gatsby shit.\n\nNut mostly i just described a normal relationship, as they all end from someone finding someone else, feeling neglected, or falling out of love and wanting to move on"

b"You do know i just described a normal relationship? They lasts until someone wants to do something else, doesn't feel like they're getting what they need, or falls in love with some else.\n\n(this is the reverse order from the original list btw)"

b"@LevitatorThe @tehbignic Especially considering we frequently spread half truths about people we've decided to be upset with, and how rumors propagate more the more delicious they are.\n\nThat's just bad design by whoever invented humans living together, but I think I'll play other games than care."

b'@DAVID_FIRTH @anon_opin Arguably the benefit to originality is you discover new ideas that way. If you discover something you REALLY like, why keep searching?\n\nI guess it depends if you love it when something works out or if you immediately lose interest as soon as you got it.'

b"Finding out they regifted the thing you were sure they'd love should not offend you, it just means they're not you. If you cared at all, you wold jump at the opportunity to get to know your friend better.\n\n... after apologizing for giving them a bad gift."
b"Good life advice is not telling them what you've done or a list of things you'd wish others did, it's figuring out what your experiences can do to help do as they want."

b'Oh and if people were to, say, use this decent explanation as incidental evidence that seems to imply I think through all my opinions and they probably make sense from some angle, that would be AMAZING for me.'

b'The rationale for this is that meta programming is so much more fun and long term beneficial it will kill the original. Best case make it a sample implemention.\n\nIt will also ruin a pure meta project with real life compromises. It will not always be either incomplete or a game.'

b"My rule for fancy adding meta programming/development mechanics like dynamic recompilers, extending asset hotswapping, or ading the ability tie any vairable to a midi input:

Do not add it unless the project started out meta.
The second you add anything not meta, it's never meta."
b"@tehbignic Skipping words, I see. I got a xanax from a friend because I was freaking out over lost sleep and have a huge party tomorrow.\n\noh yeah speaking off, i'm on twitter again aren't i"

b'@tehbignic "Why is he saying so random things".
It's because right now you're being in denial and saying things will only make them get added to your mental walls, my friend.

I said it to leave a crumbtrail for you to accidentally get curious about and them form your own thoughts.'
b'@tehbignic And the puzzle in there, how to reach through to someone, is amazingly addictive.'

b"@JayGeisGold @Johnny57438371 @SharkMelodic @Steam Now that I begrudgingly am older and wiser, I've found the path of just going with the flow is almost a guaranteed way for me to find happiness.
...until I start to expect it to bring me happiness.

b"@JayGeisGold @Johnny57438371 @SharkMelodic @Steam Success and effort seem a bit unrelated in my experience. b'This is surprisingly simple due to to the rooms snapping to each other. Just find the sweet spot where it switches from a valid snapping to an invalid overlapping position with barely any mouse movement.\n\nOh and lower your fps.'

b'If you place a room so it overlaps another room, then delete it, the room on the other side will no longer have an opening to the original room. Repeat on the other side of the wall to make it look the same from both directions.'

b'Planet Crafter has a one frame latency for checking if a structure placement is valid.\nIf you keep the mouse somewhere where the outline is green, then whip your mouse over to a new location and click really fast, you can place things anywhere. https://t.co/xqAD5G53QH'

b'@viralgreek Example: input string is a series of "X". Return "true" if there is an even amount, return "false" otherwise.

Code:
   "XXX"="X" // Remove excess pairs of X
   "XX"="true" // Set to true if a pair remains
   "X"="false" // Only happens after the previous ones have failed'

b'@viralgreek Brief explanation of A=B:
You are tasked with solving simple problems with a single instruction, A=B.
A and B are clear text strings. You make a list of instructions, and on each tick the first available A gets replaced with its B, and the process repeats.

Turing complete.'

b"@viralgreek Not any actual projects, but A=B suckered me into string substitution programming.\n\nIt's all backwards and horrible and I woke myself up to get back into working on it because I was having too much fun. (and not just with the game)"

b'Also direct example, satisfactory keeps track on what trees you cut down not by removing them to a list, but by adding them to a list of removed trees.
The rationale is that this takes up less memory.

... until you cut down entire forests.'

b"To make it clear, the user experience of someone having a possibly too slow computer being excited the game runs well only to slowly over time having things get slower the more they play... is not great.\n\nIt's like having a previous gen iphone."
b'If your goal is for the game to be busy, optimize for worst case scenarios, disregard any ideas of how it "should" run faster in a new save.'

b"If you make optimizations to make your game run faster when there's less going on, you are implicitly discouraging more busy states.\n\nUsually fine, but in, say, a city simulator, making it run at 1000 fps when the city is empty might actually hurt your end result experience."

b"@itjulienn Several thousands of hours. It's absolutely wonderful, both as an experience, as from a game design perspective. Absolute master class, even up to how they deal with the janky bits."

b"On one hand, the player absolutely wants to be able to build there if there's any part of the geometry that would be visible, especially if gaps drive them as mad as it does me. But the mental stress of knowing there's a block down there is intense.\n\nI know no simple fix."

b"One really interesting problem I'm looking forward to seeing how they address is that the game lets you build things that are completely inside the terrain (by snapping it to the bottom of another block, for example). These cannot be removed, they things will snap to them."

b"(Because it legit is too much work, especially this late in development. It would take someone really invested in the idea like a week of hardcore bingeing, but if it's jut a design point, many months)"

b"Although I do wish they'd let you cut foundations and walls along arbitrary angles yourself instead of introducing (and maintaining!) a bunch of new build options for those rare cases.\n\nThis feature is easily dismissed as too much work, however."
b"Everything else about Satisfactory, including the collectibles that don't do anything yet have this super annoying computer voice nagging you to collect them, is literally perfect."

b'The upsides I see include making for incredible vistas once you get done with things, and it certainly adds a great feeling of being inside The Factory That Must Grow. Factorio gets this too, but through sheer scale of numbers.'

b'This makes it incredibly hard to get any kind of overlook when on foot, heavily encouraging risky jetpack use (fun!) or boring hoverpack efficiency (efficient!)\n\nIt also drastically diminishes how large the world seems once you begin seeing your builds from a large distance.'

b"Speaking of Satisfactory, my only real disagreement as a game designer (I probably just don't know the full story) is the scale they chose for what you build. A basic block is 4x8x8 meters, and machines can easily have a footprint of six of these or more."

b"@akirathedon Oh.. that's a great analogy!

b'@theironlefty The grass changing colors on a large scale from area to area in Minecraft is an attempt to break up large scale monotony, and that can certainly be applied via some kind of "undetail" texture.'

b"@theironlefty Partially, yes, but I'm not ALL snarky comments. Only mostly ;)\n\nIt's also an interesting problem with no real obvious solutions. Getting rid of anti aliasing certainly helps, but it's not because math works that way, it just happens to add some basically random grit to things."
b"@trousity Almost certainly out of nostalgia, early 90's.\n\nIt took up until Satisfactory for me to be as engaged in a game as I was back then."
b'@Commanderstitch I used to think the rise of screen shake and over the top user feedback ("make it juicy!") might not survive too long, but it\'s never gotten old'

b"@Commanderstitch I feel less a need to keep things fresh, there seems to be certain looks from time to time that become timeless.\n\nThe groundbreaking search in between comes with its fair share of lens flares and bloom, but it's hard to know what will get obnoxious."
b'On distant objects or terrain, I mean. Up close is an absolutely joy these days!'

b'I was thinking of something to fill in the blurry flat look that sometimes happens in games these days.

We used to slap detail textures on things to make them look nice up close, but we got way too good at this at some point.

or perhaps we just got rid of fog'

b"@marylanda42 The instant and global accessibility is a big part of why I got into javascript after java for sure. WebGL sealed the deal. It's almost weirdly univerally supported (for no reason other than engineers loving stuff like that as far as I can tell. Maybe advertisers liked it)"

b'@pdlbackup I especially like how it makes you escape characters two levels deep. Once for regexp itself, and once to convey the escape character from your programming language to regexp.\n\nEven in javascript, which has regexp literals, you need to escape the characters making up the regexp.'

b"@marylanda42 (Sure, you could spend a lot of time setting up an environment where you do get hot swapping and rapid prototyping in C++, but at that point you've basically just reinvented a higher level language.)"

b'@marylanda42 It gets weirdly verbose about fundamental things like pointers, usually out of legacy compatibility reasons, and the long compilation times are not compatible with the rapid iteration methods I prefer.'

b"@marylanda42 It happened to be what I was primarily working in at the time. These days it would've been Javascript. If that's worse or not is probably a very entertaining conversation.\n\nAt the core, I really dislike C++. If I want low level, I'd rather go all the way and work in assembler."
b"@pdlbackup I don't know why I keep using it. It's like I enjoy the unmaintanability or something"
b"@DokDokey Yeah, it happens! I got close once, so maybe it'll happen one day! I'll definitely tweet about it if it does."
b'Bonus points for using the regexp templates in the parsing of the regexp templates themselves.'

b'@diSEBled It stared out as a legacy thing from the old design, but I keep it because it lets me drain the storage from unwanted shapes (the first filter) without just sending it all to the hub (second filter). That way the standard parts can keep flowing as much as possible for upgrades.'

b"@16p11dot2DS It used to do that, but now it branches off and feeds all 16 inputs equally.\nIf you follow the belt around, you'll notice it always splits into two similar parts, first to choose which diagonal to feed, then which specific direction, and so on."
